entry.title: Pashinyan, Aliyev may issue joint statement at White House

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan, Aliyev may issue joint statement at White House
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan and Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev may travel to Washington later this week for a potential joint statement declaring their intention to make peace. üìç The Armenian government and Russian-Armenian billionaire Samvel Karapetyan‚Äôs family issued conflicting interpretations of a new decision from the emergency arbitrator regarding the dispute over the nationalization of the Electricity Networks of Armenia. üìç One stitch at a time, Armenian embroidery finds new life: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnSs9ZSmnok

entry.title: Backlash grows over $6m state-funded Jennifer Lopez concert

media:group.media:title: Backlash grows over $6m state-funded Jennifer Lopez concert
media:group.media:description:
üìç A Sunday night concert by American pop star Jennifer Lopez in Yerevan sparked a public outcry over the Armenian government‚Äôs use of taxpayer funds to finance the event. üìç Poland said it was considering asking the EU for an exemption from Schengen rules to impose visa requirements on several countries. A Polish media report listed Armenia among them, despite the fact that Armenians already need a visa to enter Poland. üìç Armenia‚Äôs government has approved an investment project allowing a company co-owned by a close friend of Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan to acquire public land without competitive bidding. üìç THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jBJ2oPTgm0&t=1s

entry.title: One stitch at a time, Armenian embroidery finds new life

media:group.media:title: One stitch at a time, Armenian embroidery finds new life
media:group.media:description:
Over the past decade, embroiderers from different walks of life have contributed to the repopularization of the traditional Armenian art form. Originally used as a narrative canvas to illustrate stories and beliefs, traditional Armenian embroidery now stands as a tangible symbol of identity and heritage. Here‚Äôs how the craft has adapted to a modern market, while still preserving the centuries-old techniques and meanings behind its patterns and designs.

entry.title: Armenia‚Äôs Ardshinbank bids for HSBC‚Äôs Malta operations: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenia‚Äôs Ardshinbank bids for HSBC‚Äôs Malta operations: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia‚Äôs 1,000 biggest companies paid nearly $2.6 billion in taxes in the first half of the year, a year-on-year increase of about 9.5%, according to the latest quarterly top taxpayers list. üìç Armenia‚Äôs government approved plans to grow exports by 70% by 2030, earmarking more than $255 million in public money for the effort. üìç Ardshinbank, Armenia‚Äôs biggest lender, confirmed it is bidding to purchase HSBC‚Äôs Maltese subsidiary. Ardshinbank took over HSBC‚Äôs Armenian operations last year.

media:group.media:title: Roundtable: Russia‚Äôs Move South
media:group.media:description:
Renowned historians Ronald Suny, Dominic Lieven, Valentina Izmirlieva, and Thomas de Waal participate in a roundtable discussion titled "Russia's Move South." They explore Russia's centuries-long drive southward - from escaping the infertile northern lands around Moscow to conquering the fertile Black Sea steppes. Dominic Lieven examines Catherine II's decisive victories over the Ottoman Empire that transformed the balance of power. Thomas de Waal contrasts different imperial strategies: American-style colonization in "New Russia" versus brutal conquest in the North Caucasus and co-optation of elites in the Transcaucasus. Valentina Izmirlieva reveals the ironic story of Russian refugees finally reaching Constantinople - not as conquerors but as exiles who transformed Ottoman urban culture. Ronald Suny challenges Cold War narratives about Soviet formation, showing how the empire emerged from civil war complexity rather than simple Russian conquest. The roundtable was held on June 27 in Batumi as part of a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The 2025 Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Batumi, Yerevan, and Tbilisi from June 25 to July 13.

entry.title: Akhuryan Reservoir: How Armenia and Turkey Share Water

media:group.media:title: Akhuryan Reservoir: How Armenia and Turkey Share Water
media:group.media:description:
Armenia‚Äôs largest reservoir, Akhuryan, was launched under a USSR-Turkey interstate agreement and is still managed through technical cooperation between the two sides‚Äîdespite the absence of diplomatic relations. How are the water allocations determined? What happens at monitoring stations? What risks do new Turkish dams pose, and is Armenia adequately prepared and protected?
